section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards Oo and Pp, drawing and writing supplies, Alphabet Books On the Box and Paint

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Connect to Large Group Today we read Close Your Eyes. We saw the letter o in the word own and the letter p in the word stop.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Oo Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letter Oo. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase O. The letter O makes the /o/ sound you hear in the word octopus. This is lowercase o. The letter o makes the /o/ sound you hear in ostrich.

Teach Pp Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letter Pp . Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase P. The letter P makes the /p/ sound you hear in the word penguin. This is lowercase p. The letter p makes the /p/ sound you hear in peach.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Share On the Box. Today we will read this book about the letter Oo and then we will read a book about the letter Pp.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud On the Box with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Clap your hands when you hear a word that begins with the /o/ sound or has the /o/ sound in it.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud Paint with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Tap your ears when you hear a word that begins with the /p/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Oo and Pp. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read On the Box, stop at each word that begins with the letter Oo. Have children say /o/ and the word that begins with Oo. Repeat with Paint and the letter Pp. For children who need assistance, before writing have them trace letters in salt or sand.

Encourage children to name other words that begin with Pp. It’s challenging to suggest categories, such as names of foods that begin with /p/. Next, ask children to name other words that have the /o/ sound as in box and rhyme with box, or words that rhyme with top.

When reviewing the letter sounds for Oo and Pp by saying different words that begin with those sounds, always respond by repeating the letter sounds and names. For example, if a child answers that otter begins with /o/, say “Yes, otter begins with the /o/ sound.” Then, show the letter card and say: “/o/ is the sound of the letter O.”

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials paper circles, small paper circles, craft stick, glue, crayons or markers

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Where’s My Teddy? We met a little boy with a big imagination.
We talked about Eddie’s feelings and the bear’s feelings when they lost and then found their missing teddy bears. We know how they felt and what they did.
Let’s make bear puppets. Then we can talk about how your bear can act when he feels happy, sad, surprised, angry, or scared.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Show children how to add small circles for ears to a big circle. Then have them watch as you add eyes, a nose, and a mouth to your puppet. Show them how to glue a stick to the circle to make the puppet.
Set Up Have children create their puppets. Provide help as needed. Let all the children finish before moving on.
Ask Have children hold up their bear puppets and take turns completing sentences such as the following:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: When I am a happy bear I show it by ....
When I am an angry bear, I show it by ....
When I am a disappointed bear, I show it by ....

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About It Extend the conversation by having children talk about their own feelings and what they do when they have those feelings.

Help children participate in the conversation by asking specific concrete questions. For example, say “When you are happy, do you smile or giggle?”or “When you are angry, do you pout or stamp your feet?”

Challenge children by asking them to complete these scenarios with a word that names a feeling: Bear was crying because
. Bear was giggling because
. Bear was growling because
. Bear was surprised because
. Bear was hiding because .

Multilingual learners sometimes need extra help because they may lack the language skills to convey their emotions. Help saying the incomplete sentences and having them act out their answers and then supplying the language.
For children who still find it difficult to draw features on a face, ahead of time prepare stickers for them to use for the eyes, nose, and mouth. Have a helper help them place the stickers.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Connecting Cubes, two books of different sizes

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Where’s My Teddy? We read about a little boy and a gigantic bear, and a little teddy bear and a big teddy bear. Comparing the sizes of two things can be fun!
Today, we will measure our friend’s foot and compare it to our own. There are lots of ways to measure something.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hold up a book. If I measure this book using Connecting Cubes, I wonder how long it is. Let’s measure! Put the book on the table. Have children count as you connect Cubes. Announce the outcome: This book is [16] Connecting Cubes long! Repeat with a smaller book.
Set Up Have children work with partners.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Use Connecting Cubes to measure your partner’s foot. Lay the Connecting Cubes next to your partner’s foot. When the row of Cubes is as long as their foot, count the cubes. How many Cubes long is it?
Now have your partner measure your foot in the same way. How many Connecting Cubes long is your foot?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Whose foot is longer? How do you know?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About It I measured my foot with Connecting Cubes too! Hold up the Cubes. How can we put the Connecting Cube rows in size order? Let’s start with the shortest cube row. Who can find it?
Continue, having children place Connecting Cube rows in size order from shortest to longest. Any duplicates can remain in order.

Have each partner stand on a piece of paper. Draw lines on the paper to mark the heel and toe, and then have the child step away. Use a ruler to draw a straight line from toe to heel. Now students can more easily measure by placing Cubes directly on the straight line.

Encourage children to predict how many Cubes long they think their foot and their partner’s foot will be before they begin measuring. How close were they? Was it easier to predict the number of Cubes for the first or second foot? Why?

Learning about measurement introduces all children to new vocabulary. To help multilingual learners, use an online language translator or call on family support, before beginning this lesson. Learn the following measurement terms and phrases in the language of your multilingual learners: How long? How many? How big? When teaching, use English, followed by their home language, and then English again.

Connecting Cubes are a great way for children to strengthen their fine motor skills. If the activity is too difficult for some learners, connect cubes in a variety of lengths ahead of time. Children can line up sets of the Connecting Cubes alongside their partner’s foot. Have them try different lengths until they find the one that matches.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Cotton ball, book, pencil, block, Connecting Cubes, straw, and other light and heavy objects, scale (balance or digital)

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the I Can Measure poster. We saw how we can measure using a ruler, a scale, cups and a thermometer.
Today, we will compare two things, guess which is heavier, and then see if we guessed correctly by using a scale to measure their weights.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hold up a cotton ball and a book. Have children predict which is heavier. Invite children to volunteer to place each the items on the scale. Which is heavier—the book or the cotton ball? How do you know? If you have digital scale, compare the weight numbers and show how one is greater than the other; if you have a balance scale, show how one size is lower than the other.

Ask Present two objects, such as a pencil and a large building block. Ask children which one they think is heavier. Then, invite two children to place the two different items on the scale. Which is heavier? How do you know?
Repeat Repeat the activity with a variety of items until all objects have been weighed.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Comparing two items is one way to measure things.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: How can we measure two things to find out which is heavier?

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-talk: What happens to the side on the balance scale that has the heavier object?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: If children find it difficult to make predictions about which object they think is heavier, have them close their eyes as you place an object in each hand. Then ask: Which feels heavier? Continue, by placing these objects on the scale and having children observe.

Invite children to draw a seesaw with two animals. Have them show the animal that is heavier on the side of the seesaw that is down and the animal that is lighter on the side of the seesaw that is up.

One of the goals of this activity is to engage all learners in the process of scientific inquiry and investigation. Here are a few strategies that teachers can use to help multilingual learners accomplish this: Use actual objects, provide small-group learning with English speakers, and help children engage in hands-on exploration. Learning about measurement introduces all children to new vocabulary.

Encourage children to touch the objects being weighed and observe some of the physical characteristics that make one object heavier than another. For example, a rock is heavier than tissues rolled up into a ball of similar volume. Allow children to explore their ideas and predict the results before they weigh the objects.
